comments:
This seminar course is about the contributions of basic sciences (neuroanatomy,
neurophysiology, neurochemistry, and neuropharmacology) to an understanding of
behavior and behavioral disorders. It discusses important psychiatric disorders, primarily
from the viewpoint of their biological aspects. Emphasis is placed on critical evaluation
of research strategies and hypotheses.
Students seemed to love this course saying that it was a course where “you’re
expected to think, not memorize.” They also felt that the knowledge they gained was
“extremely valuable” and even caused a few to “consider a career in psychiatry.” Many
students also found the guest lectures to be incredibly useful.
Students raved about Professor Lexow claiming that she “did a wonderful job of
stimulating student interest.” Many students also attested to Lexow’s passion and
enthusiasm.
Overall, students highly recommended the course due to the sheer amount the
material learned. However, some found the number of presentations overwhelming.
Nevertheless, the course is great for anyone interested in psychiatric disorders.
